item.title: US seeks closer China ties
item.description: Barack Obama sought to recast America’s the US relationship with China, urging Beijing to be its partner and forge deeper ties with Washington on the economy, climate change and nuclear proliferation

item.title: BP profits more than halve to $3.14bn
item.description: Europe’s second-biggest oil company reported second-quarter profits down more than a half at $3.14bn, but that was ahead of most analysts’ expectations and the company said cots cuts were ahead of schedule

item.title: Investment banking bolsters Deutsche
item.description: Deutsche Bank’s second-quarter net income rises to €1.1bn thanks to a rebound in its investment banking operations

item.title: Gates discusses security and arms sales in Iraq
item.description: Robert Gates, US defence secretary arrived in Iraq on Tuesday to discuss security issues and arms sales as the two nations look toward the gradual withdrawal of all US forces by the end of 2011

item.title: Hitachi falls to loss and bids for units
item.description: Known as the GE of Japan, Hitachi reported a first quarter net loss of Y82.7bn and said it saw only limited economic improvements

item.title: US to increase clarity on short-sellers
item.description: US regulators will share more detailed information on short-selling activity with the public as they move to boost transparency of the trading that was blamed for fuelling market turmoil during the financial crisis

item.title: New US home sales surge in June
item.description: New house sales in the US jumped by 11 per cent in June, providing some of the strongest evidence yet that the housing market has bottomed out after being savaged for three years

item.title: Verizon to slash 8,000 jobs
item.description: Verizon, the second largest US telecommunications group, is to cut a further 8,000 jobs as part of its effort to cut costs in its traditional fixed line business and improve ­sagging margins

item.title: China’s push for talent tests party values
item.description: A drive to entice talented ‘sea turtles’ into state companies and education – but, so far, not government departments – runs against Communist party doctrine

item.title: Abu Dhabi backs Branson’s space tourism push
item.description: Aabar, an Abu Dhabi state-linked investment vehicle, plans to acquire a 32% stake in Virgin’s commercial space venture in the latest sign of the oil-rich emirate’s rising ambitions
